prompt: Facts: Criminal Appeal No. 755 of 2019 arising out of SLP(Crl.) No. 8824 of 2018.; Appellant (Vikram Johar) challenged the order dated 04.09.2018 passed by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad.; The High Court dismissed the Application under Section 482 CrPC filed by the appellant.; The application sought quashing of Charge-Sheet No. 1 dated 07.07.2017 arising out of Case Crime No. 0117 of 2017.; Charges were under Sections 420 (Cheating) and 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).; The case was registered at Police Station Sector 20, Gautam Budh Nagar, Uttar Pradesh.; The dispute originated from an Agreement to Sell dated 19.03.2013 between the appellant (seller) and Respondent No. 2/Complainant (buyer) for a property.; Complainant alleged payment of Rs. 1 crore towards the sale consideration.; Complainant alleged that the appellant failed to execute the sale deed as per the agreement.; Complainant further alleged that the appellant failed to return the amount paid despite demands.; FIR was lodged by Respondent No. 2 on 13.03.2017.; Investigation led to the filing of the charge-sheet under Sections 420 and 406 IPC.; Appellant contended before the High Court and Supreme Court that the dispute was purely civil in nature, arising out of a breach of contract.; Appellant argued that the ingredients of cheating (dishonest intention *ab initio*) and criminal breach of trust (entrustment and misappropriation) were not made out from the FIR/Charge-Sheet.; Supreme Court analyzed whether the allegations, taken at face value, disclosed offenses under Sections 420/406 IPC or if it was primarily a civil dispute. | IPC: Section 406 (Punishment for Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 420 (Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), Section 405 (Criminal Breach of Trust - Definition, discussed), Section 415 (Cheating - Definition, discussed)
